fields.summary: 4.2 Upgrade not finding existing DNS service and then registering a second DNS service.

comments.body:
We have a customer that is seeing this issue and they are seeing the following error when using euca2ools after de-registering the new DNS service. ( see SUP-587 )
{code}
error: connection error (('Connection aborted.', gaierror(-2, 'Name or service not known')))
{code}

[~spark] Questions:
 1) In 4.2 what should the new DNS service registration look like so that we can get the customer running again?
 2) Why was the original service not found in DNSUpgrades.groovy line #60?
 3) where did the original service properties get changed?
[~mmunn1], it looks like the cloud controller and UFS are the same host in this deployment, if so this may be a factor.

[~mmunn1] 
1) I think it is safe for them to register DNS service again. Try using euca-register-service (deprecated, but still working).
euca-register-service -T dns -H 10.196.140.15 -P API_15  -p 8773 API_15.dns
2) Not sure about this. In upgrade case, we do not register a new DNS (which should be handled in DnsUpgrades.groovy #48) and we tested this. I suspect this may be due to the changes in the entity representation of Dns.class (so querying Dns type service doesn't return), but this is just a theory.
3) I don't understand the question. Can you elaborate?

So the first thing to do for this customer is to register DNS service again and see if it starts the DNS socket.

[~sjones] No everything is co-located except the CC?

[~mmunn1] Please ignore my previous comment. I looked up the sos report and it appears DNS listeners were started. I think the upgrade groovy has a bug in that it registers a new DNS where it should not. However, I am unsure if that caused the DNS issue that the customer is facing.
[~spark] So how should the dns service look in euca-describe-services now after the upgrade?
[~mmunn1] The existing dns service should remain the same. But before putting any fix in, I think we should find out what caused the dns outage for this customer (or co-located UFS/CLC).

[~mmunn1] [~jcarroll] Here's what I found:
 * Looking through the sos report, it appears DNS upgrade was executed as expected and there was only one dns service right after the upgrade.
{noformat}
Mon Oct 26 17:42:35 2015  INFO [DnsUpgrades$Dns420RegistrationUpgrade:main] Registering DNS service on host 10.196.140.15
Mon Oct 26 17:42:35 2015  INFO [ServiceConfigurations:main] :1445895755319:ServiceConfigurations:bootstrap:COMPONENT_REGISTERED:ServiceConfiguration dns arn:euca:bootstrap:eucalyptus:dns:10.196.140.15_dns/ 10.196.140.15:8773:/services/Dns:vm-local:host-local:PRIMORDIAL
{noformat}
I compared this with my own upgrade logs and the script indeed register the dns service again but results in only one DNS service with updated names (this answers [~mmunn1]'s question about updated names).

 * Then they tried to register API service type (UFS) again (which is unnecessary).
Mon Oct 26 18:22:46 2015  INFO [ComponentRegistrationHandler:New I/O worker #357] Using builder: ApiEndpointServiceBuilder for: API_15.API_15@10.196.140.15:8773
Mon Oct 26 18:22:46 2015  INFO [ComponentRegistrationHandler:New I/O worker #357] Returning existing registration information for: API_15.API_15@10.196.140.15:8773
Mon Oct 26 18:22:46 2015  INFO [ComponentRegistrationHandler:New I/O worker #357] Using builder: DnsServiceBuilder for: API_15.API_15.dns@10.196.140.15:8773

* This results in the second DNS service. 

So to summarize, having multiple dns service doesn't appear to be an upgrade bug, but may have caused by their attempt to register UFS service again.
It is unclear if the DNS outage is related to DNS service registration. In theory as long as there is one DNS service, DNS socket should start listening on.

[~mmunn1], if the cloud is using lower case identifiers (which is the default) then the only issue is that the cloud property cannot be changed (which is fine, as you should never change this property on a cloud with existing resources)
[~sjones] yes it is set to 'lower' so it should not be a problem.
